data.author: Fishinggardener
data.content: I expect the bidding to be as lacklustre as the trading update. This sounds like "pitch-rolling" to me... Preparing the investors for a poor performance even when it comes to disposing of the company. £17.7m EBITDA, times  a multiple of 6, which is what a PE house would bid to give them some upside, values the company at £102m. Take off the debt which at year end I expect to be at circa £24m, gives an enterprise value of  £78m, or 76p per share. If I were a buyer, I would interpret todays RNS as a reason to chi the price, and so for that reason, having been here for 3 years, I have taken the benefit of the recent rise, and got out at an overall profit of c £5k. Best of luck to those of you who remain, but on this occasion ....a bird in the hand and all that.! FG

data.author: Fishinggardener
data.content: I agree with your sentiment IP, about Opportunist investors swooping when the heavy lifting has been completed, and as others have said subsequent to your post, it is going to be down to whether or not the Board hold out for a realistic valuation as to whether or not this ends happily for us.. In that respect, having competitive bidders is definitely a good thing and will help our cause. I too have been here 3+ years, - my highest price paid of £1.24 for a tranche in summer 2023, but having been able to trade some of the volatility on its way down, I now have an all-time average  of just under 55p, on a holding of c50,000 shares, and so from that point of view returning back to the black, is welcomed by me. However, if i were to be critical, in the 3 years that I have been invested, the board have continually posted trading results which have disappointed - there has always been one reason or another as to why the numbers have missed, and we have to wait another period. ...and it is this inability to manage city expectations which, in my view accounts for a lot of the downward drift in price from the £1.25 highs of summer '23 to the 40s in recent weeks. After the Trump Tariffs episode,  I had got to the point where I was thinking my money could work harder for me elsewhere, and so on balance, I hope that one of these bids succeeds, but at a fair valuation. .... having said that, I too think that on balance, with the VIetnam factory now up and running, and with the business trading profitably and generating cash, as it it, then, if it is sold, I am confident that it will go for a price north of £1. Adjusted EBITDA for the  current year is going to be c£15m - £16m, and with cash generation of c80 - 100% of this figure. So, a profitable business, - albeit troubled by the uncertainty of tariffs. - that has seemingly run out of steam / starting to go backwards. So a 5 - 6x multiple of this would be bordering on a firesale.  5 x 15m is £75m. 6 x £16m is £96m.  Add a bit of premium for competitive bidding, and I can see £101m being paid, which equates to £1 per share. The story is good. The scale is fully formed, and distribution looks fit for purpose....it has just been an underwhelming ride for the past 3 years, and therefore it is probably in the best interests of the business for another team to have a go. FG

data.author: Fourprinces
data.content: For anyone asking where the 70–80p talk comes from, it’s just basic maths. At 55.5p the market cap’s around £57m, with net debt of ~£25m, so EV about £82m. For a global eyewear group turning over ~£200m, that’s 0.4x sales – cheap. Most trade buyers or PE funds pay 0.6–0.8x sales for consumer brands with margin recovery potential. Even 0.6x gets you close to £120m EV, which after debt equates to roughly 75p a share. Inspecs also owns strong labels – Superdry, Barbour, Radley, Ted Baker, etc – plus vertical manufacturing in Vietnam. Streamlined costs and new management mean EBITDA normalising next year, so 6–7x forward multiple is realistic. Two credible bidders already in play and a third sniffing around assets. If either party wants exclusivity, they’ll have to go north of 70p. My view: anything under that and the board will hold out. 75p looks fair value – 80p possible if a strategic comes in.

data.author: oilpeak2019
data.content: The analysis of Inspecs Group plc (SPEC.L), a designer, manufacturer, and distributor of eyewear operating a vertically integrated platform , indicates that the company is currently priced below its intrinsic value, reflecting acute market concerns regarding revenue contraction and near-term liquidity management. The current market capitalization stands near £74.2 million, translating to an Enterprise Value (EV) of approximately £110.2 million. Based on the midpoint of the company's FY2025 guidance, this implies a forward EV/EBITDA multiple of approximately 6.23x, representing a significant discount to the company’s most relevant publicly traded peer, Safilo Group (median EV/EBITDA of 8.3x). The current valuation discount is rationalized by persistent net losses, two consecutive years of revenue decline, and the material disclosure of a debt covenant breach earlier in 2025. However, management’s successful execution of synergy extraction and cost control, evidenced by the projected margin expansion, provides a clear pathway for valuation re-rating. Investment Conclusion Inspecs demonstrates operational resilience by improving margin quality despite macroeconomic challenges. The target intrinsic value range anticipates the market re-rating the stock as operational stability and Free Cash Flow (FCF) generation are proven. * Intrinsic Share Price Value Range: 95 pence – 125 pence per share. * Mid-Point Target: 108 pence. This mid-point target represents substantial potential upside from the current price (approximately 72 pence). The realization of this value is strictly conditional upon the mitigation of material balance sheet risks and sustained delivery of the stated profitability targets. Recommendation HOLD/NEUTRAL. A BUY recommendation is inappropriate given the acute liquidity sensitivities demonstrated by the recent cash flow cover covenant breach , which increases investment risk significantly. A SELL recommendation is unwarranted given the deep discount to peers and the promising margin expansion indicated in the latest trading update. The position is maintained as neutral until firm evidence of sustained FCF generation and reduced working capital burden is provided in forthcoming results.

data.author: Fishinggardener
data.content: I expect the bidding to be as lacklustre as the trading update. This sounds like "pitch-rolling" to me... Preparing the investors for a poor performance even when it comes to disposing of the company. £17.7m EBITDA, times  a multiple of 6, which is what a PE house would bid to give them some upside, values the company at £102m. Take off the debt which at year end I expect to be at circa £24m, gives an enterprise value of  £78m, or 76p per share. If I were a buyer, I would interpret todays RNS as a reason to chi the price, and so for that reason, having been here for 3 years, I have taken the benefit of the recent rise, and got out at an overall profit of c £5k. Best of luck to those of you who remain, but on this occasion ....a bird in the hand and all that.! FG

data.author: stargate
data.content: Bullish weekly outside price bar, implies future sp target of 85.6, calculated as outside bar range X 2, added to outside bar high. RSI(relative strength index) above value of 50 on both daily and weekly charts indicates uptrend status. Weekly RSI bullish failure swing, where RSI crossed above it's previous swing high Volatility based Bollinger bands are separating on both daily and weekly charts indicating rapid sp movement.  The sp is above the Parabolic SAR used to provide trailing stop values, on both daily & weekly charts which is bullish. PSAR could be considered for a stop value if a buy. DYOR.

data.author: Fishinggardener
data.content: I agree with your sentiment IP, about Opportunist investors swooping when the heavy lifting has been completed, and as others have said subsequent to your post, it is going to be down to whether or not the Board hold out for a realistic valuation as to whether or not this ends happily for us.. In that respect, having competitive bidders is definitely a good thing and will help our cause. I too have been here 3+ years, - my highest price paid of £1.24 for a tranche in summer 2023, but having been able to trade some of the volatility on its way down, I now have an all-time average  of just under 55p, on a holding of c50,000 shares, and so from that point of view returning back to the black, is welcomed by me. However, if i were to be critical, in the 3 years that I have been invested, the board have continually posted trading results which have disappointed - there has always been one reason or another as to why the numbers have missed, and we have to wait another period. ...and it is this inability to manage city expectations which, in my view accounts for a lot of the downward drift in price from the £1.25 highs of summer '23 to the 40s in recent weeks. After the Trump Tariffs episode,  I had got to the point where I was thinking my money could work harder for me elsewhere, and so on balance, I hope that one of these bids succeeds, but at a fair valuation. .... having said that, I too think that on balance, with the VIetnam factory now up and running, and with the business trading profitably and generating cash, as it it, then, if it is sold, I am confident that it will go for a price north of £1. Adjusted EBITDA for the  current year is going to be c£15m - £16m, and with cash generation of c80 - 100% of this figure. So, a profitable business, - albeit troubled by the uncertainty of tariffs. - that has seemingly run out of steam / starting to go backwards. So a 5 - 6x multiple of this would be bordering on a firesale.  5 x 15m is £75m. 6 x £16m is £96m.  Add a bit of premium for competitive bidding, and I can see £101m being paid, which equates to £1 per share. The story is good. The scale is fully formed, and distribution looks fit for purpose....it has just been an underwhelming ride for the past 3 years, and therefore it is probably in the best interests of the business for another team to have a go. FG

data.author: Fourprinces
data.content: For anyone asking where the 70–80p talk comes from, it’s just basic maths. At 55.5p the market cap’s around £57m, with net debt of ~£25m, so EV about £82m. For a global eyewear group turning over ~£200m, that’s 0.4x sales – cheap. Most trade buyers or PE funds pay 0.6–0.8x sales for consumer brands with margin recovery potential. Even 0.6x gets you close to £120m EV, which after debt equates to roughly 75p a share. Inspecs also owns strong labels – Superdry, Barbour, Radley, Ted Baker, etc – plus vertical manufacturing in Vietnam. Streamlined costs and new management mean EBITDA normalising next year, so 6–7x forward multiple is realistic. Two credible bidders already in play and a third sniffing around assets. If either party wants exclusivity, they’ll have to go north of 70p. My view: anything under that and the board will hold out. 75p looks fair value – 80p possible if a strategic comes in.

data.author: oilpeak2019
data.content: The analysis of Inspecs Group plc (SPEC.L), a designer, manufacturer, and distributor of eyewear operating a vertically integrated platform , indicates that the company is currently priced below its intrinsic value, reflecting acute market concerns regarding revenue contraction and near-term liquidity management. The current market capitalization stands near £74.2 million, translating to an Enterprise Value (EV) of approximately £110.2 million. Based on the midpoint of the company's FY2025 guidance, this implies a forward EV/EBITDA multiple of approximately 6.23x, representing a significant discount to the company’s most relevant publicly traded peer, Safilo Group (median EV/EBITDA of 8.3x). The current valuation discount is rationalized by persistent net losses, two consecutive years of revenue decline, and the material disclosure of a debt covenant breach earlier in 2025. However, management’s successful execution of synergy extraction and cost control, evidenced by the projected margin expansion, provides a clear pathway for valuation re-rating. Investment Conclusion Inspecs demonstrates operational resilience by improving margin quality despite macroeconomic challenges. The target intrinsic value range anticipates the market re-rating the stock as operational stability and Free Cash Flow (FCF) generation are proven. * Intrinsic Share Price Value Range: 95 pence – 125 pence per share. * Mid-Point Target: 108 pence. This mid-point target represents substantial potential upside from the current price (approximately 72 pence). The realization of this value is strictly conditional upon the mitigation of material balance sheet risks and sustained delivery of the stated profitability targets. Recommendation HOLD/NEUTRAL. A BUY recommendation is inappropriate given the acute liquidity sensitivities demonstrated by the recent cash flow cover covenant breach , which increases investment risk significantly. A SELL recommendation is unwarranted given the deep discount to peers and the promising margin expansion indicated in the latest trading update. The position is maintained as neutral until firm evidence of sustained FCF generation and reduced working capital burden is provided in forthcoming results.

data.author: Fishinggardener
data.content: I expect the bidding to be as lacklustre as the trading update. This sounds like "pitch-rolling" to me... Preparing the investors for a poor performance even when it comes to disposing of the company. £17.7m EBITDA, times  a multiple of 6, which is what a PE house would bid to give them some upside, values the company at £102m. Take off the debt which at year end I expect to be at circa £24m, gives an enterprise value of  £78m, or 76p per share. If I were a buyer, I would interpret todays RNS as a reason to chi the price, and so for that reason, having been here for 3 years, I have taken the benefit of the recent rise, and got out at an overall profit of c £5k. Best of luck to those of you who remain, but on this occasion ....a bird in the hand and all that.! FG
